Topic: Illustrate plants with and without water.
Level Description: Advanced (complete and accurate representation of all elements)
CAN: The student can illustrate a plant that has water and is healthy, showing vibrant green leaves and strong stems.
The student can illustrate a plant that lacks water and is not healthy, depicting wilting leaves and drooping stems.
The student can include detailed differences between the plant with water and the plant without water, like variations in leaf color and stem uprightness.
The student can use observed patterns such as wilting or color changes to explain why plants need water to live and grow, possibly through annotations or labels in the drawing.
The student can incorporate a comparison in the drawing, such as side-by-side illustrations, to highlight the importance of water for plants.
CANNOT: The student might occasionally neglect to label some parts of the plant, like roots or stems, although these are shown accurately *(minor labeling gap)*.
The student may sometimes miss including one or two minor details in the comparison because they assume the differences are self-explanatory *(natural variation in detailing)*.
